articles.content:
Wreath Laid before Bust of Kim Jong Suk 
    Pyongyang, December 22 (KCNA) -- Officials in charge of cultural and friendly relations of foreign embassies here Wednesday laid a wreath before the bust of anti-Japanese war hero Kim Jong Suk at the Revolutionary Martyrs Cemetery on Mt. Taesong on the occasion of the 88th anniversary of her birth.
 The guests laid the wreath before her bust in humble reverence and observed a moment's silence. Woman general of Mt. Paektu Kim Jong Suk devoted all her life to the sacred cause for liberation of the country and happiness of the people under the leadership of President Kim Il Sung.
 Written on the ribbon of the wreath were letters reading "The Revolutionary Feats of Anti-Japanese War Hero Comrade    
Kim Jong Suk Will Be Immortal!"

articles.content:
One More S. Korean Peasant Dies 
    Pyongyang, December 22 (KCNA) -- Peasant Hong Tok Phyo, who was heavily wounded by brutal violence of the police and taken to the hospital of Wonkwang University in Iksan, North Jolla Province, lost his life at the hospital on Dec. 18,  according to the south Korean MBC.
 He participated in the "national rally of peasants" held in Youido of Seoul On Nov. 15 to check the ratification of a bill on rice negotiations by the "National Assembly" and he was seriously hit on his neck, head and other parts of the body by shields of the riot police during a demonstration and he was paralyzed all over.    
 This murder case sparked off indignation among the south Korean public including the south Korean Federation of Peasants Associations.
 The federation said that one more peasant Hong died after the death of Jon Yong Chol by the reckless police suppression and repeatedly demanded the resignation of the chief of the "National Police Office", an apology of the "government" and so on.

articles.title: Police Authorities Urged to Apologize for Their Violent Crackdown upon Peasants' Actions
articles.content:
Possession of Depleted Uranium Bullets by U.S. Troops in S. Korea Disclosed 
    Pyongyang, December 22 (KCNA) -- It was disclosed that the U.S. troops in south Korea have a large number of depleted uranium bullets, according to south Korean CBS.
 The south Korean Internet Thongil News on Dec.19 said that a declassified document of the U.S. officially confirmed that a great deal of depleted uranium bullets are kept at the U.S. air bases in Osan, Suwon and Chongju of south Korea and in Kadena, Okinawa of Japan.    
 It has been proved again that the U.S., which has deployed a large number of depleted uranium bullets, a radioactive weapon denounced by the world, in and around south Korea in a bid to ignite a new war on the Korean Peninsula, is, indeed, a vicious criminal country severely violating the security of the Korean nation and world peace.

DPRK Government Delegation to Visit China
    Pyongyang, December 22 (KCNA) -- A government delegation of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea led by Ro Tu Chol, vice-premier of the DPRK Cabinet, will visit China from Dec. 24 to 27 at the invitation of the government of the PRC.
